Headline.Para: Global Affairs; How to stop rise of rogue nuclear powers

LeadPara.Para: Israel's pre-emptive strike against Syria in 2007 offers lessons on current crises involving North Korea and Iran

LONDON • Timing, as they say, is everything. So, when the Israeli government recently admitted, more than a decade after the event, that it was indeed responsible for destroying a nuclear reactor in Syria back in 2007, diplomats and analysts concluded that the revelations were intended more as a topical warning.

TailParas.Para: After all, Israel's responsibility for that fateful air raid on the Syrian reactor on the night of Sept 5, 2007 was always one of the Middle East's worst-kept secrets; Israel's military footprint was obvious within days after the raid, and although Israeli officials kept mum, their operation was subsequently documented in every book written by every single senior member of the US administration.
What is the point, therefore, to assume responsibility for an attack everyone knew was carried out by Israel, unless the Israelis want to warn that they could do the same thing in Iran?

The reality is, however, more complicated. For Israel's decision to release information about its destruction of the Syrian nuclear reactor was prompted more by the fact that two former Israeli prime ministers are about to publish their memoirs and both claim ownership for ordering what became one of the Israeli military's most spectacularly successful operations; maintaining official silence over this affair was, therefore, no longer feasible.
INTELLIGENCE FAILURES

Nevertheless, the revelations do offer some pertinent lessons for today's nuclear stand-offs with Iran and North Korea. And they raise broader questions about how the global threat of nuclear proliferation could have been tackled.

The first and perhaps most striking conclusion is about the inherent limitations of intelligence services in some of these nuclear cases. Syria has always been one of the key targets for Israel's spooks and the Jewish state's intelligence agencies knew from at least the 1990s that Syrian President Hafez al-Assad, the father of the country's current ruler, was interested in acquiring nuclear research facilities.
ST ILLUSTRATION: MANNY FRANCISCO

But no Israeli spy chief or politician appears to have "connected the dots" or raised the alarm about what may be happening until late in 2006, when Syria already was in the final stages of building its nuclear reactor, and even then, the revelations came indirectly, through the uncovering - initially by Britain's spies - of a parallel nuclear programme in Libya, another Arab country then aspiring to nuclear status.

Those Western leaders who currently claim that the nuclear challenges of Iran and North Korea defy any "good solutions" are well advised to ponder whether we are in these no-solution outcomes precisely because we dismissed too quickly and too glibly some of the solutions that Israel deployed when other countries sought to go down the nuclear road.

So, although the destruction of the Syrian reactor now comes across as a major triumph of Israeli ingenuity, the fact remains that the episode started with a major intelligence cock-up; as General Yaakov Amidror, one of Israel's former national security advisers, points out, the Syria nuclear reactor "is the story of a terrible intelligence failure that ended well".

Mr Tamir Pardo, who led the Mossad, Israel's much-vaunted intelligence agency, is now even more explicit: "On the one hand, there was an echoing failure to detect the nuclear core for an extended period, but on the other hand, there was complete luck in finding the nuclear core in a place no one would have expected."

Israel's apparent information failure is not unique; rather, it's the norm in all nuclear episodes. For Western intelligence agencies were taken by surprise when the Soviets detonated their first nuclear charge in 1949, when the French detonated theirs in 1960, when Israel itself acquired nuclear capability during the late 1960s, when India followed suit a decade later, or when Pakistan became a fully fledged nuclear power in the 1990s.
And that's not because intelligence agencies are not intelligent, but because it is inherently difficult to measure scientific progress.
WHEN TO STRIKE

The Syria story also offers another significant lesson: that doing nothing when confronted by evidence of a country trying to acquire nuclear weapons illegally (Syria was a signatory of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons) could be just as dangerous and perhaps even more reckless than contemplating using force in order to destroy that capability.

As the Israelis were preparing for their military strike on Syria in 2007, they were implored to seek a negotiated outcome. Then US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice urged the "use of diplomacy"; so did Turkish leader Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who at that time was on good relations with both Israel and Syria and actually conducted secret talks between the two nations.

Had the Israeli government accepted such mediation offers - as it was urged to by its Western allies and as it would have been encouraged to do by almost every armchair strategist - Syria would have insisted on its right to build a reactor to generate electricity, just as Iran has done, would have dragged the process for years, and the nuclear reactor would have existed to this day, only to fall into the hands of Islamic State in Iraq and Syria terrorists, who until November last year controlled the region where the reactor was to have been built.

Of course, none of those Israeli leaders who chose to reject negotiations back in 2007 knew what would happen to Syria in the years to come. But their counter-intuitive hunch that diplomacy was actually more dangerous than the use of force proved to be absolutely correct. And so was their other counter-intuitive guess: that instead of using massive force to destroy the target, the real novelty was to use as little force as possible in the most targeted way feasible, in order to allow Syria an elegant way of pretending that nothing had happened, and thereby avoid a bigger war.

In purely military terms, Israel's destruction of a similar nuclear reactor in Iraq in 1981 was more dangerous and technically challenging than the destruction of the Syrian reactor a quarter of a century later. The Iraqi target was further afield from Israel, Iraqi air defences were both more capable and powerful, and Israel's air force did not have the mid-air refuelling capabilities it has today; none of these problems presented themselves in Syria in 2007.
HAS THE WINDOW CLOSED?

Still, Israel encountered the same policy dilemma on both occasions. The best time to destroy a nuclear reactor is before it goes "hot"; once it becomes operational, the reactor's destruction risks widespread and unacceptable environmental damage. But the justification to use force is at its least politically compelling when the reactor is inactive and when it presents little threat.

Yet, by the time the use of force becomes justified because the reactor is active, deploying force also becomes unthinkable because of the corollary damage it is sure to cause. Israel brushed this dilemma aside and acted early in Iraq and Syria.
But nobody did the same in confronting North Korea or Iran decades ago, and the choice of using force has now largely passed.
Notwithstanding certain similarities, the Syrian episode cannot be compared with the nuclear challenge from Iran or North Korea.

Both countries are far more advanced down the nuclear road. Both have a greater "depth" of nuclear knowledge, so even if some nuclear installations were pre-emptively destroyed, that will only delay rather than avert a nuclear programme. And Iran relies on centrifugal enrichment of uranium, a process that can be dispersed and concealed.

Both North Korea and Iran also have greater conventional military capabilities of retaliation, and a far bigger incentive to retaliate, for their nuclear programmes are seen as far more essential to the survival of their regimes than was the case with Syria.

And while the Syrian nuclear project was conducted in great secrecy and even some of the country's top officials did not know about it, the North Korean and Iranian nuclear programmes have the status of national obsessions. The result is that, while the Syrian President was able to ignore the loss of his reactor without the loss of face, the Iranian and North Korean leaders cannot ignore a similar attack against their nuclear installations.

Still, those Western leaders who currently claim that the nuclear challenges of Iran and North Korea defy any "good solutions" are well advised to ponder whether we are in these no-solution outcomes precisely because we dismissed too quickly and too glibly some of the solutions that Israel deployed when other countries sought to go down the nuclear road.
